title: History of Medicine
description: Explore the fascinating milestones in the history of medicine!

questions.question: Who is often called the 'Father of Medicine'?
questions.explanation: Hippocrates of Kos (c. 460-370 BC) is widely regarded as the Father of Medicine. He established medicine as a profession distinct from philosophy and superstition.

questions.question: Who developed the first successful smallpox vaccine in 1796?
questions.explanation: Edward Jenner developed the smallpox vaccine by using cowpox material to create immunity, laying the foundation for modern immunology.

questions.question: What did Alexander Fleming accidentally discover in 1928?
questions.explanation: Alexander Fleming discovered penicillin when he noticed that a mold called Penicillium notatum killed bacteria in a petri dish he had left uncovered.

questions.question: Who discovered that germs cause disease, founding the germ theory of medicine?
questions.explanation: Louis Pasteur proved that microorganisms cause disease, developed pasteurization, and created vaccines for rabies and anthrax.

questions.question: What medical imaging technology was discovered by Wilhelm Roentgen in 1895?
questions.explanation: Wilhelm Roentgen discovered X-rays in 1895 and won the first Nobel Prize in Physics in 1901 for this groundbreaking discovery.

questions.question: Who introduced antiseptic surgery in the 1860s?
questions.explanation: Joseph Lister pioneered antiseptic surgery by using carbolic acid to sterilize surgical instruments and clean wounds, dramatically reducing post-operative infections.

questions.question: Which ancient text is the foundation of traditional Chinese medicine?
questions.explanation: The Huangdi Neijing (Yellow Emperor's Classic of Internal Medicine) is the foundational text of traditional Chinese medicine, written over 2,000 years ago.

questions.question: Who performed the first successful human heart transplant in 1967?
questions.explanation: Dr. Christiaan Barnard performed the first successful human-to-human heart transplant on December 3, 1967, at Groote Schuur Hospital in Cape Town, South Africa.

questions.question: What did Frederick Banting and Charles Best discover in 1921?
questions.explanation: Banting and Best discovered insulin at the University of Toronto, transforming diabetes from a fatal disease into a manageable condition.

questions.question: Florence Nightingale is known as the founder of which profession?
questions.explanation: Florence Nightingale founded modern nursing during the Crimean War and established the first professional nursing school at St Thomas' Hospital in London in 1860.

questions.question: Which disease was declared eradicated by the World Health Organization in 1980?
questions.explanation: Smallpox was officially declared eradicated in 1980 following a global vaccination campaign, making it the first human disease to be completely eradicated.

questions.question: Who is credited with developing the polio vaccine in 1955?
questions.explanation: Jonas Salk developed the first effective inactivated polio vaccine, which was announced as safe and effective in 1955. He famously refused to patent it.

questions.question: What medical practice did Ignaz Semmelweis champion that was initially rejected by the medical community?
questions.explanation: Ignaz Semmelweis discovered that handwashing with chlorinated lime dramatically reduced childbed fever deaths, but his ideas were rejected for decades before being accepted.

questions.question: The Hippocratic Oath, still referenced by doctors today, originates from which era?
questions.explanation: The Hippocratic Oath originated in Ancient Greece around the 5th century BC. Modern versions of the oath are still taken by medical graduates worldwide.

questions.question: What revolutionary medical tool did Rene Laennec invent in 1816?
questions.explanation: Rene Laennec invented the stethoscope in 1816 after feeling it inappropriate to place his ear directly on a female patient's chest. His first version was a rolled-up paper tube.
